The texture of the catalyst support is a crucial factor for H2O2 decomposition due to the expansion of H2O2 in monopropellant thrusters, which can lead to overpressure and catalyst breakage. Therefore, alumina supports with 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose templates were studied to create macropores. MIP and SEM analysis showed that microcrystalline cellulose template increases the macropore fraction. Low-concentration H2O2 decomposition experiments revealed that over 10 wt% microcrystalline cellulose prevented catalyst breakage. Additionally, the thermal durability of the catalyst was studied at different calcination temperatures. Alumina with 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose and a 900 °C calcination temperature exhibited the highest fracture strength and suitable reaction kinetics. The catalysts were tested in high-concentration H2O2 monopropellant thruster. The results demonstrated enhancement in catalyst size retention, pressure stability, and pressure drop. Introducing macropores through microcrystalline cellulose addition overcomes unstable thruster performance and it extends catalyst lifespan in H2O2 monopropellant thrusters’ applications. Monopropellants and bipropellants are the two types of liquid propellants [1]. Monopropellants do not require fuel and oxidizer, and just one exothermically decomposing substance is sufficient. They are preferred in small missiles and satellite engines with low thrust requirements. The ignition systems of the monopropellant engine can be designed in two ways. Firstly, ignition is achieved by external energy sources such as friction, pyrotechnics, or lasers. The important parameter is the energy density, which should be high enough to obtain a sustained reaction in a limited volume. Difficulty in restarting the ignition and requiring a power supply are the drawbacks of this ignition system. In the second method, a suitable catalyst facilitates the decomposition of the monopropellant. This type of decomposition reaction usually has high activation energies, and the reactants do not react spontaneously at ambient conditions. Instead of heating up for the thermal decomposition, the activation threshold could be decreased with the catalyst [2]. The critical point of such thrusters is the appropriate propellant-catalyst interaction. The main requirements of the monopropellants depend on the objectives of the mission (duration, specific impulse, response time, etc.). Crucial properties of a monopropellant include its storability, compatibility with space grade materials, and toxicity. The catalytic decomposition systems are classified into two thrust ranges: 1–22 N for satellites and spacecraft and 100–400 N for launch vehicles. As the most preferred propellant, hydrazine (N2H4) and its derivatives give high catalytic decomposition performance with the development of the Shell S405 catalyst [1]. Hydrazine has long term storability, can readily be decomposed using a catalyst, and it exhibits high Isp performance [3,4]. However, the toxic and carcinogenic nature of the hydrazine induces costly difficulties in handling, transportation, and storage. At this point, low toxicity (or "green") liquid rocket propellants have recently gained popularity as potential replacements for hydrazine propellants [5–7]. Many global entities contributed to accelerating the research activities of green propulsion systems with projects such as Green Advanced Space Propulsion (GRASP), Replacement of Hydrazine for Orbital and Launcher Propulsion Systems (RHEFORM) [8–10]. Among all the green monopropellants, highly concentrated hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) has taken renewed interest due to its environmentally safe nature [4,11]. Hydrogen peroxide concentrations of 80–85 % was already extensively utilized as an oxidant or single component propellant in a variety of rockets and aviation engines, including the V-2, Redstone, Viking, and Jupiter, during the 1940s and 1950s [12]. Due to its higher performance and long duration storability, hydrazine rose to prominence in 1960’s. However, recently the toxicity of hydrazine has led to an interest in using hydrogen peroxide as a monopropellant and oxidant for satellite thrusters, landers, and gas generators [13–15]. The catalytic decomposition of highly concentrated hydrogen peroxide produces a hot oxygen and water vapor mixture by releasing exothermic heat. Depending on the concentration of hydrogen peroxide solution used, the adiabatic decomposition temperature rises (632 °C for 85 wt% H2O2, 755 °C for 90 wt% H2O2, and 953 °C for 98 wt% H2O2). The catalyst's performance during H2O2 decomposition depends on its lifetime, activity for the desired reaction, mechanical strength, and thermal shock resistance [13,16,17]. The main catalysts mostly preferred in H2O2 thrusters are silver and platinum metals and manganese oxides [8,12,17–20]. Palmer et al. studied the performance and the lifetime of a silver gauze catalyst on 87.5 wt% H2O2 decomposition. They compared silver gauze that contains 20 mesh and 0.356 mm diameter wire with 0.5 % platinum on an alumina catalyst [17]. Carlotti and Maggi investigated the characteristics of an alumina-supported manganese oxide catalyst in the pulsed and long-burn steady-state thruster tests. 83.5 % H2O2 was used, and 88 % temperature efficiency was reached [21]. Rusek examined the efficiency of manganese oxides and platinum supported on alumina in the rocket grade hydrogen peroxide [20]. Among the catalysts, the melting point of silver is close to the 90 % hydrogen peroxide decomposition temperature, which limits its use in high concentration H2O2 applications. Additionally, platinum is an expensive raw chemical as an active material. Based on these arguments, manganese oxide is the most preferable catalyst in terms of both stability and economic viability. It is also shown that manganese oxide gives better activity after repeated firings [22]. It is important for the decomposition of H2O2 to select the best support (carrier)-active material combination for the catalyst. Although the monopropellant's decomposition is catalyzed by the active phase, its low surface area causes a low catalytic reaction rate. Hence, coating the catalyst on a support material that has a high specific surface area is used as a strategy to increase the reaction rate. Thermal and mechanical strengths, coupled with a high specific surface area are crucial properties for the support material. The most preferred ceramic support material is porous aluminum oxide because of its high surface area and high temperature stability. It can be manufactured in different shapes and sizes, depending on the catalyst bed design. Pasini et al. studied an alumina sphere-supported catalyst for 5 N hydrogen peroxide thrusters [22]. An and Lee compared monolith honeycomb and alumina pellet support materials with 90 % H2O2 [5]. In the catalytic bed of the thrusters, the catalysts are exposed to harsh conditions like impurities, high temperatures, and cyclic thermal and mechanical loading. As the reaction temperature rises, the likelihood of thermal shock in ceramic materials also rises. When liquid hydrogen peroxide gets into the pores of the catalyst support, it rapidly decomposes, leading to the gaseous reaction products that generate high pressures within the micropores of the catalyst due to the high volumetric expansion. These factors contribute to catalyst breakage, which may lead to flow instabilities in the thrusters. Pasini et al. tested 87.5 % H2O2 catalytic decomposition with the catalyst made of γ-Al2O3 support, and they observed that cracking of the catalyst causes the progressive occlusion of the catalyst bed and incomplete decomposition [22]. Kang et al. studied lanthanum doped alumina support for manganese oxide catalyst in the 50 N hydrogen peroxide thruster. Lanthanum increased the mechanical and thermal resistance of the catalyst and improved its lifetime [23]. Also, Jang et al. demonstrated that doped 13 % silicon dioxide, α- Al2O3, may withstand several heat cycles in a thruster without displaying any structural damage [24]. The mechanical stability of the catalyst can be controlled with higher calcination temperatures, the addition of dopants, or by changing the textural character of the catalyst support to resist volumetric gas expansion in the pores. The macro- and mesopore sizes could be helpful for the diffusion of the reactant and the decomposition products through the catalyst [25]. The pore size can be represented by micro- (< 2 nm diameter), meso- (2–50 nm diameter), and macro- (>50 nm diameter) dimensions. Combustible additives such as polymer microspheres, carbon materials, and microcrystalline cellulose, among others, could be used as a template to produce a mixture of macro- and mesopore structures [11,18,19,26]. These materials are burned out after catalyst samples are calcined thus, large mesopores or macropores can be obtained. Among the additives, microcrystalline cellulose, which has an average particle size of 20–90 µm encourages the formation of macropores [9–11]. The macropore on the catalyst improves the internal diffusion and material flux for both gases and liquids [27–29]. Traditional mesoporous alumina catalysts usually have a high surface area and temperature resistance, but a lack of diverse porosity results in cracking of the catalyst and instability of thrusters. In the literature, methods such as reducing the catalyst size or using hexaaluminate structures with very high calcination temperatures are applied to increase the mechanical and thermal resistance of propellant catalysts [22,23,26,30–32]. However, reducing catalyst size can increase the possibility of occlusion problems. Also, structures such as hexaaluminate crystals and high-calcination structures result in a low surface area, which can lead to a decrease in catalytic efficiency and thruster performance [32]. In this study, the requirements of the catalysts for the efficient decomposition of rocket grade hydrogen peroxide propellant were discussed and a scientific approach was presented to enhance the lifespan of the thruster catalyst. The focus of the study was the preparation of a catalyst capable of maintaining its activity through diffusion-limited reactions and ensuring stable operation in thrusters. Initially, the experimental procedure was explained in detail. In this section under controlled process conditions, the microcrystalline cellulose was added to the Al2O3 support as a template. Next, the impact of microcrystalline cellulose on the textural properties of the alumina support using both MIP and gas sorption methods was investigated. The analysis showed that microcrystalline cellulose provides better pore size distribution with an increasing macropore fraction on the support. It allowed the hot gas products to discharge without damaging the structural integrity of the catalyst. The high decomposition temperature of rocket-grade hydrogen peroxide in the thruster's catalytic bed increased the risk of thermal degradation of the catalyst pellets. Therefore, in the following section, the effects of calcination temperature on the chemical, textural, and mechanical properties of the synthesized catalyst were thoroughly explored. Lastly, in-house tests with an 87.5 % H2O2 monopropellant thruster to demonstrate how the proposed catalyst performs in real-life scenarios, particularly during extended firing durations were explained. The unstable performance of thrusters caused by cracking of the pellet catalyst was solved by modifying the catalyst's porosity. Namely, catalysts with a microcrystalline cellulose template showed stable performance with a low pressure drop over the catalyst bed. The results showed that when using a microcrystalline cellulose, the systems lasted twice as long as the other catalysts, making it a robust catalyst for hydrogen peroxide monopropellant thrusters. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Materials Boehmite having a surface area of 244 m2 g-1, pore volume of 0.39 cc/g and pore diameter of 4.8 nm, 99 wt% acetic acid as a peptizing agent, and microcrystalline cellulose with a 20 µm powder size as an additive were used in the preparation of the alumina paste. The manganese salt manganese (I1) acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(Ac),·4H20) and distilled water was used in the impregnation process. 2.1.2 Preparation 2.1.2.1 Support paste preparation The alumina support was prepared via the extrusion of a paste. Acetic acid was used as a peptizing agent instead of nitric acid because of safety concerns with the microcrystalline cellulose additive. Boehmite was mixed with an agent and water, and then the paste was dried at room temperature for 1 day. Another alumina support formulation was prepared via the addition of microcrystalline cellulose into the solid mixture of boehmite, which was thoroughly mixed at 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 15 wt% ratios. Then, peptization and drying processes were applied. The prepared paste was extruded by using an automated hydraulic press and press die to obtain 2 mm-long cylindrical extrudates. Then, the samples were dried at room temperature for 1 day, and they were broken into 2 mm lengths. At the end, the extrudates were calcined at 600 °C. After selecting the convenient cellulose ratio, different calcination temperatures were tested namely, 700 °C, 800 °C, and 900 °C. The image of extrusion process for the support material is presented in Fig. 1. 2.1.2.2 Impregnation The catalyst support was impregnated with manganese salt via the wet impregnation method for 2 h at room temperature. The impregnation was continued with vacuum drying at 70 °C for 24 h afterward, it was calcined at 400 °C where MnO2 activity is high. After that, heat treatment effect on the catalyst mechanical performance was considered. Both the support and the catalyst were calcined at the same temperature as 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C. The schematics of the synthesis process were given in Fig. 2. 3 Catalyst characterization techniques 3.1 BET surface area The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured by Micrometritics ASAPmin a surface area analyzer. Before performing each measurement, samples were degassed at 300 °C for 6 h to get rid of water and other impurities. The adsorption and desorption isotherms were determined at relative pressures ranging from 0.0019 to 0.9934 and from 0.9934 to 0.14 respectively. 3.2 Mercury intrusion porosimeter (MIP) Mercury porosimeter was carried out on a Micromeritics Instrument Corporation AutoPore IV 9500 V1.09 device to determine the pore size distribution of the synthesized catalysts. 3.3 X-ray photoelectron and X-ray diffraction Analysis Surface analysis to synthesize MnOx catalysts was performed on a Thermo K-alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) equipped with Al-Kα radiation. The scanning spectra of Mn 2p, Mn 3s, and O 1 were recorded in the binding energy range of 0–1300 eV. The correction of the energy offset was done by using C 1s peak of the carbon as a standard. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was also performed on the support materials. Analysis was carried out on Bruker D2 Phaser and all diffraction patterns were obtained in the 2θ range of 10–80° with an angular step size of 0.02. 3.4 SEM-EDX images The morphologies of alumina were carried out by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The surfaces were prepared for analysis by depositing a portion of the solid onto a carbon adhesive tape that is fixed to a sample holder. The images were acquired with magnifications ranging from 100x to 1kx. 3.5 Catalytic activity Catalytic activity experiments were performed via the laboratory apparatus shown in Fig. 3. The glass tempering beaker was a liquid-jacketed borosilicate glass vessel, equipped with a double-walled casing to circulate warm or cold tempering fluid. The batch reactor had a volume of 500 mL, and its temperature was kept constant at 25 °C by circulating water. The catalyst samples (weight: 750 ± 0.1 mg) were maintained in the 6 % H2O2 solution (Vsol: ± 1 cm3). The 6 % H2O2 was chosen to keep heat output under control during the decomposition and to maintain safe conditions in the laboratory. The solution sample was taken with a syringe in every measurement, and then the solution in the syringe was poured into the beaker by using filters. The portable density meter device (Anton Paar Portable Density Meter: DMA 35 model) measured the weight concentration and density of every H2O2 solution. The decomposition of H2O2 follows apparent-first order kinetics: (1) ln H 2 O 2 = ln H 2 O 2 0 + k app t (2) k app = A e E A app / RT where H 2 O 2 (mol L -1) is the H2O2 concentration at time t (min) and H 2 O 2 0 (mol L -1) is the initial H2O2 concentration, k app (min-1 gcatalyst -1) is the apparent first-order rate constant, E A app (kJ. mol-1) is the apparent activation energy, R is molar gas constant (8.314 J K-1 mol-1), and A is the preexponential factor. 3.6 Crushing strength measurement The side crushing strength test is the most typical test used for the characterization of the mechanical strength of the support material [33,34]. In this test, there is a diametral compression of a cylindrical sample between two plates, and it measures the tensile strength of the sample, called the crushing strength. In this work, support materials that have different calcination temperatures were used to compare their mechanical properties. After the support mixture was calcined, the samples were selected as having the closest cylindrical form and a length of 3–4 mm. The measurement was performed with a 1 kN Shimadzu AGS-X universal testing machine. The supports were loaded at a rate of 0.05 mm/min until failure, and the load vs. displacement curve was recorded. 20 samples were taken for each support types. 4 Results & discussion 4.1 The effect of microcrystalline cellulose addition to the support The ceramic catalyst support was prepared by the extrusion method, and the pellet shape was preferred to permit gas flow and to impregnate all pores with active material easily. The calcination temperature of Al2O3 support was chosen as 600 °C because of the high surface area property of γ-phase aluminum oxide and it was analyzed that raw microcrystalline cellulose degradation is completed before 600 °C. During the decomposition reaction of H2O2, gas products expand at a 4000-times ratio [35]. It causes difficulty in discharging from the pores and results in catalyst cracking. In order to eliminate the cracking problem, microcrystalline cellulose was added as a template, and the changes on the support surface were determined. The representative nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and their associated pore size distributions show the textural characteristics of the 0, 5,10 and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose templated alumina supports ( Fig. 4a). The microstructure of the catalyst supports is given in Table 1. Every curve agrees with the IUPAC type IV pattern, which is typical for mesoporous materials [36]. Also, the hysteresis of the samples follows H2 type by IUPAC classification [37]. The very steep desorption branch, which is a defining trait of H2(a) loops, can be related to either cavitation-induced evaporation or pore-blocking/percolation in a narrow range of pore necks. The size distribution of neck widths is much wider for the Type H2(b) loop [37]. As it can be observed from the isotherms each hysteresis belongs to the type H2 with connected pore structure. Al2O3 sample in Fig. 4a has a steeper desorption curve which can be correlated by narrow mesopore distribution and narrow range of pore openings. For Cel/Al2O3 samples, the hysteresis loop has more curvature related to the H2(b) type with a wider pore opening in the connected mesopore network. At each amount of cellulose loaded alumina, there is a linear increase in gas uptake compared to the neat Al2O3 sample which is speculated to have a larger pore remaining in the sample at higher p/po regions (0.9 <). According to the textural analysis in Table 1, 0 wt%, 5 wt%, 10 wt% and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose increase the BET surface area of alumina from 195.1 m2. g-1 to 205.7 m2. g-1, 202.6 m2. g-1 and 206.1 m2. g-1 respectively. Mesopore volume was calculated based on the BJH model [33]. When the ratio of mesopore volume to total pore volume was examined, it was seen that the volume occupied by the mesopores was decreasing with increasing microcrystalline cellulose amount. This is related to the increasing macropore volume with increasing microcrystalline cellulose content from 0 to 15 wt%, since it is known that there are no micropores on the support. However, there is only a slight increase observed in surface area and total pore volume due to the cellulose addition with gas sorption analysis. Results show that the textural change on the support due to cellulose addition is on a much larger scale. Porosity analysis from gas sorption methods usually ignores macropores which are larger than 50 nm. For this reason, mercury porosimeter analysis was conducted to investigate pore structure in larger scale. Fig. 5a shows the intrusion-extrusion curves of different amounts of cellulose-loaded alumina samples. As it can be observed from the intrusion curves, increasing cellulose content as a sacrificial template results in higher uptake values, 0.38 cc/g, 0.48 cc/g, 0.58 cc/g and 0.67 cc/g for 0 wt%, 5 wt%, 10 wt% and 15 wt% Cel samples, respectively. The Al2O3 sample without any cellulose addition shows a steep increase in mercury volume in the mesopore region. Using 5 wt% cellulose seems to have a limited effect on the macropore volume. Nonetheless, 10 wt% and 15 wt% Cel samples have a substantial increase in pore volume at low pressure (macropore) region. The intrusion-extrusion curves of all samples demonstrated hysteresis. After the completing depressurization during extrusion process, some mercury remains inside the pores or entrapped because the intrusion into pores cannot be entirely reversed [36–38]. Generally, this entrapment is explained by the fact that the throat or entrance opening to a pore is usually smaller than the actual cavity and connected nonuniform and complex pore [39]. Pore size distribution of the samples is presented in the Fig. 5b. As shown in the graph, the Al2O3 sample has a very narrow pore size distribution around 6 nm in the mesopore region. Nonetheless increasing cellulose amount on the support causes a minor increase in pore diameter from 6 nm to 8.6 nm and wider pore size distribution. According to the Fig. 5b, 5 wt% cellulose has a slight effect on Al2O3 pore structure. However, 10 and 15 wt%Cel/Al2O3 samples also alter porosity in the macropore region. Pore diameters over 100 nm can be clearly seen in the 15 wt% Cel sample. The wider pore distribution of the cellulose templated samples is also observed by the BJH pore size distribution curve obtained by gas adsorption results which are presented in Fig. 4b. The BJH pore size distribution curve gives a more detailed look in the mesopore region. For the Al2O3 sample, after 25 nm pore diameter, there isn’t any measurable gas uptake. Nonetheless, cellulose addition improves the gas uptake volume in whole mesopore region up to 50 nm especially for 15 wt%Cel/Al2O3 sample. Therefore, using microcrystalline cellulose as a sacrificial template in the alumina support successfully generates multi-scale porosity and a wider distribution of pores at the catalyst. Moreover, bulk density and skeletal densities were found to calculate specific pore volume and were taken from mercury porosimeter analysis for 0, 5, 10 and 15 wt% cellulose loaded alumina. The bulk density, also called apparent density, is the ratio of the material mass to the occupied space of the material. Total volume of the material was measured, including open and closed pores of the material. The skeletal density is the ratio of the material mass to the volume, ignoring any internal voids or pores. The main distinction between bulk density and skeletal density is that while skeletal density only considers the density of the solid component, bulk density takes into consideration all the empty spaces and porosity within a material as a volume. Bulk density usually has a smaller value than skeletal density. Differences between skeletal density and bulk density give the material empty space (total pore volume). (3) Porosity = 1 − ρ bulk / ρ skeletal (4) V sp = 1 / ρ bulk − 1 / ρ skeletal (5) V macro = V sp − V 0.99 where ρ bulk is the bulk density (g.cm-3), ρ skeletal is the skeletal density (g cm-3), V sp is the specific pore volume (cm3 g-1), V 0.99 is the total pore volume measurable by N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of P/P0 = 0.99, and V macro is the macropore volume (cm3 g-1). According to the MIP data, the total porosity of the samples increases from 52.60 % to 65.01 % with increasing micro cellulose content. Also, the macropore volume of each support sample was calculated using Eqs. (3)–(5) by assuming gas adsorption data only represent mesopore volume [40]. According to the calculation, the addition of microcrystalline cellulose has gradually enhanced the macropore volume in the alumina support which are shown in Table 2. Pure Al2O3 sample has no macroporosity. Also, the addition of 5 wt% microcrystalline cellulose provides a negligible amount of macroporosity on the support. Besides, 10 and 15 wt% Cel samples have substantial amounts of macropores, 0.16 and 0.24 cm3/g, respectively, which correspond to almost 28 % and 36 % of the total pore volume for 10 wt% and 15 wt%Cel sample. The threshold pressure, permeability, and tortuosity properties of the support samples were investigated to obtain a more detailed textural description. Fig. 5c demonstrates that the applied pressure in psi was plotted against the mercury saturation percentile. In the alumina sample without cellulose addition, only about 12.9 % of mercury could enter its pores until reaching pressures of approximately 27,500 psi. However, as cellulose is introduced, the threshold pressures start to decrease slightly. The crucial point here is that while the microcrystalline cellulose percentage is increased, the amount of mercury entering the pores before obtaining the threshold pressures also increases, which are 25 %, 46 %, and 52 % for 5 wt%,10 wt% and 15 wt%Cel/Al2O3 respectively. This demonstrates that the alumina with cellulose addition has a higher porosity and larger pores, which has allowed mercury to enter the pores more easily. For the determination of the tortuosity of the alumina support, we used Eq. (6) which is the principle of tortuosity calculation proposed by Carniglia [36,41–43]. The equation contains the bulk density, pore volume that were taken from the Hg porosimeter and BET surface area results from gas sorption analysis. According to the tortuosity correlation, ε term is 1 for the cylindrical pores [36]. The calculation results are given in Table 2 and show that the addition of cellulose leads to decreasing tortuosity values from 2.46 to 2.12, making the flow easier through the pores, and therefore, the diffusion pathway follows a straighter route than pure alumina. For the calculation of the support samples’ permeability, the Kozeny-Carman relationship, which describes permeability corrected in terms of the tortuosity, was used and given in Eq. (7) [36,44–46]. Table 2 shows that the permeability of the alumina increases with the addition of microcrystalline cellulose from 0.56 to 1.77 nm2, since larger pores provide more pathways for fluid flow, resulting in higher permeability. (6) τ = ( 2.23 − 1.13 V total × ρ b ) ( 0.92 × ( 4 S ∑ ∆ V i d i ) 1 + ε ) (7) K = ϕ d p 2 16 τ where τ is the tortuosity, V total is total pore volume (cm3 g-1), ρ b is bulk density (g-1 cm-3), S is the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (m2/g), ∆ V i is change in pore volume within a pore size interval i (cm3 g-1), d i is the average diameter within a pore size interval i, ε is the pore shape exponent, K is permeability (nm2), ϕ is porosity, d p is the average pore diameter (nm). The impact of microcrystalline cellulose on the texture was assessed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). In Fig. 6(a, b, and c), the surface characteristics of alumina supports without microcrystalline cellulose are given. The flat surface of the raw support can be seen. Fig. 6(d,e,f) shows that the porous alumina structure is formed using a microcrystalline cellulose template. It is clearly seen that macropores over 50 nm are visible in the Cel/Al2O3 compared to Al2O3 at a magnification of 1 kx. As expected, during calcination, the gas formation by combustion of the microcrystalline cellulose provides larger pores in the Cel/Al2O3 sample. At low magnification images (100 x, 500 x), a homogenous distribution of the larger pores on the support surface can be observed. These pores can facilitate mass and heat transfer during H2O2 decomposition. After the determination of the structure of the catalyst supports, the properties of the active material impregnated catalysts are also investigated. EDX analyses were conducted to determine the active manganese content of the catalyst. Manganese mass percentages in the MnOx/Al2O3 and MnOx/Cel/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Table 3. The presence of fewer and smaller pores compared to MnOx/Cel/Al2O3 has led to the accumulation of active material on the surface of MnOx/Al2O3. The higher pore volume of MnOx/Cel/Al2O3 allows easier access to active sites, leading to in better performance. This observation is presented in Fig. 7b as a comparison of the decomposition rates of the powder form of these catalysts, and in Table 4, where the apparent rate constant results. It is discussed in detail in the following paragraph. It is understood that the microcrystalline cellulose template improves macropore formation on the catalyst. The contribution of the cellulose addition to the mechanical properties of the catalyst is studied. In the laboratory, kinetic experiments were conducted with a low concentrated hydrogen peroxide solution. The aim of the experiments is to determine the required microcrystalline cellulose amount to prevent the catalyst from breaking. 5, 10, and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose were added to the catalysts during the preparation, and they were compared with the reference sample (0 wt% cellulose). At the beginning of the experiments, the particle size of all samples was selected as 800–1000 µm. The mechanical variances on the catalysts were investigated by varying the particle size. They were dropped into a hydrogen peroxide solution and allowed to soak. The breaking of the catalysts was clearly visible to the human eye in catalysts with less than 10 % microcrystalline cellulose. Fig. 7a. shows the first order catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide solution with time. The apparent rate constants are the 0.04, 0.038, 0.018 and 0.012 min-1 gcatalyst -1 for catalysts with 0, 5, 10, and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose template, respectively (Table 4). The reason for the faster decomposition rate in catalysts prepared with 0 wt% and 5 wt% microcrystalline cellulose is that the reducing particle size increases the accessible surface for the reactants. At the end of the experiment, the catalyst was filtered and dried to determine the fine particles created as a result of mechanical breaking. The sieve analysis was applied to a catalyst with an 800 µm mesh. The particle size distribution of all samples was determined. According to the analysis, the catalysts with 0, 5, 10, and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose template are able to maintain particle sizes of 0 %, 20 %, 95 %, and 100 % respectively (Table 4). Since the catalysts with 10 % and 15 % cellulose added did not break, their dimensions remained larger than those of the other broken catalysts. In order to eliminate the pellet size effect and better estimate the microcrystalline cellulose loading effect on the catalyst’s activity, 0 and 15 wt% samples were tested in the powder form. The catalyst that is not used microcrystalline cellulose template does not show its apparent decomposition rate correctly, since its cracking provides much more reaction surface to the reactant. There is a fluctuation in the first order reaction rate. Therefore, the activity of the powder catalysts is determined without the influence of particle size. Fig. 7b. shows the first order catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide solution with time for the powder form of catalysts. As shown, catalysts with 0 wt% and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose template have 0.181 min-1 gcatalyst -1 and 0.224 min-1 gcatalyst -1 apparent rate constants respectively. The catalyst with 15 wt% micro-cellulose template show the higher decomposition rate than other catalyst. This observation is related to the increased pore sizes because larger pores provide the easier discharging the reaction products from the catalyst surface. Therefore, the required microcrystalline cellulose amount was selected as 15 wt% to have mechanical stability on the catalyst. 4.2 The effect of calcination temperature The 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose template provides to catalyst better mechanical stability. Also, preventing the catalyst pellets from the thermal degradation of the catalyst due to high decomposition temperature of rocket grade hydrogen peroxide should be studied. For this purpose, different calcination temperatures for the support and the catalyst material are tried. The support material was calcined at 600 °C and the catalyst after impregnation was calcined at 400 °C. The selection of these calcination temperatures was based on the following reasons: 1) Aluminum oxide was calcined at 600 °C due to its high surface area of γ-phase structure. 2) For manganese oxide catalyst, manganese acetate tetrahydrate impregnated and dried catalyst was calcined at 400 °C to obtain MnO2 phase, which represents a good activity in the decomposition of H2O2. However, at the time of monopropellant thruster tests, the catalysts are already exposed to a higher temperature since during the decomposition reaction, the temperature reaches approximately 900 °C. In order to produce temperature resistant catalysts, the calcination temperatures should be close to the exposure temperatures. Although manganese oxide was calcined at 400 °C to produce MnO2, according to XPS results, there were multiple energy peaks that indicated a variety of manganese phases such as MnO, Mn2O3, and MnO2. Since the catalyst contained a significant amount of Mn2O3 phase, which is the second active phase for decomposition, calcination at high temperatures posed no harm. Thus, in this part of the studies, the effect of higher calcination temperatures on the catalyst is examined. Both the support and the catalyst were calcined at the same temperature as 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C. The textural feature of the catalyst supports is derived from N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. The BET surface area, pore size, and total pore volume data obtained are listed in Table 5. The table shows that the BET surface area of 15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c600 is 206.1 m2. g-1. In fact, increasing the heating temperature decreases the surface area of the catalyst, resulting in a value of 131.2 m2. g-1 for the catalyst calcinated at 900 °C. This reduction is attributed to the sintering and collapse of the porous network caused by the elimination of water and gases during the heating process. The increased diffusivity of the molecules due to the higher temperatures results in a more crystalline (ordered) network. Moreover, Fig. 8 shows how the XRD patterns of Al2O3 change at different temperatures of calcination. The alumina phase transformation at 600–1000 °C is the γ, δ, θ, α-Al2O3 respectively [47] . At low temperatures, the diffraction peaks are broad and diffuse because of the amorphous nature of the alumina. Increasing the calcination temperature causes an improvement in the crystallinity with a narrower of XRD diffraction peak. The transition from γ-Al2O3 to δ- Al2O3 is also seen after calcination at 800◦C because δ- Al2O3 gives rise to its diffraction peaks at 32o and 39o. δ-Al2O3 generally consists of both mesopores and macropores with larger pore size compared to γ-Al2O3 because increasing calcination temperature causes the sintering of particles and enlarges the pore diameter [48]. The sintering of particles is related with the decreasing surface area as seen in BET analysis results at higher calcination temperatures. δ-Al2O3 is a more chemically and thermally stable phase. Therefore, for acidic chemicals such as hydrogen peroxide and high-temperature and long firing duration operating conditions during decomposition reaction, δ- Al2O3 is more suitable as a support material of the catalyst. Also, the side crushing strength tests were conducted to examine the mechanical strength of microcrystalline cellulose templated alumina supports with different calcination temperatures. Fig. 9 shows that before the fracture, loads for the support catalysts calcined at 600 °C, 700 °C, 800 °C and 900 °C, are 20.46, 24.34, 28.66 and 31.25 N respectively. The increase in calcination temperature has enhanced the mechanical stability of the catalyst. This observation is consistent with the results of both the XRD analysis and the crushing strength test. The presence of a more stable phase, which provides an increase in the crystalline fraction and, therefore, good crushing strength at high calcination temperatures, suggests that the catalyst can maintain its structural integrity under the stresses of catalytic reactions. Following the assessment of the support structure, the characteristics of the catalysts with active material impregnation were also observed. Surface analysis to synthesize MnOx catalysts on the porous alumina support was performed on XPS analysis. MnOx catalysts with different calcination temperatures were analyzed. The spectra of Mn 2p, which was a spinorbit couplet as 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 with differing binding energies of 653.8 eV and 641.8 eV, are shown in Fig. 10. The Mn 2p3/2 spectra has three peaks by deconvolution that have 640.2–640.8 eV, 641.6–641.8 eV, and 643.2–643.6 eV binding energies, and they correspond to Mn2+, Mn3+and Mn4+, respectively. The XPS spectra was fitted by the Gaussian function for all catalysts and the example of the MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c700 sample spectra is shown in Fig. 11. Table 6 illustrates the Mn4+/(Mn2++Mn3+) ratio of the catalysts at the different calcination temperatures. Although it is desired to produce only the first effective phase, MnO2, there is already 3 different manganese oxide phases, as seen in the reference sample catalyst (MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c600). According to the table, the ratio decreases with increasing calcination temperature. MnO2 is only stable up to 500 °C and converts to Mn2O3, which is the second active phase, at higher temperatures [49]. Since the catalysts are already exposed to high temperatures (>500 °C) in the catalytic bed of the thruster and they still have the Mn2O3 phase, there is no harm in calcining at high temperatures to improve the thermal durability of the catalyst. Moreover, the kinetic experiments were done with a low-concentrated hydrogen peroxide solution. The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts has been compared by their apparent reaction rates. The alteration of H2O2 concentration with time at different temperatures (20–35 °C with a temperature step of 5 °C) is given in Fig. 12. The comparative plots reveal that the activity was significantly influenced by temperature, as expected. The apparent rate constants (min-1 gcatalyst -1) were calculated by considering first-order reaction kinetics, and the calculated values are given in Table 7. For all experiments, a 45-minute reaction time was set due to the complete decomposition of H2O2 for the sample calcined at 600 °C. The apparent reaction rate increases with increasing reaction temperature from 20 °C to 35 °C. For a 600 °C calcined sample, the apparent rate constant increases from 0.013 min-1 gcatalyst -1 to 0.019 min-1 gcatalyst -1. For 700 °C, 800 °C, and 900 °C, the apparent rate constants increase from 0.012 min-1 gcatalyst -1 to 0.017 min-1 gcatalyst -1, from 0.09 min-1 gcatalyst -1 to 0.013 min-1 gcatalyst -1, and from 0.01 min to 1 gcatalyst -1 to 0.016 min-1 gcatalyst -1 in the 20–35 °C range, respectively. The results show that the apparent reaction rate reduces with increasing calcination temperature (Table 7). The apparent rate constants at different temperatures could be used to calculate the apparent activation energy of the catalyst. It is an important parameter for figuring out the catalyst’s performance. The relation between the reaction rate of the liquid mixture and the temperature follows the Arrhenius law (Eq. 2). The activation energy was calculated by plotting the logarithm of the reaction rate constant as a function of 1/temperature as shown in Fig. 13. Depending on the slope of the fitted curve, the apparent activation energies of the reaction are calculated to be 17.8 kJ. mol-1, 19.6 kJ. mol-1, 19.9 kJ. mol-1, and 23.8 kJ. mol-1 for MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c600, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c700, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800, and MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 catalysts, respectively. High calcination temperatures lead to a decrease in the surface area of the catalyst, which is one of the reasons for the lower apparent rate constant values and higher activation energy. Since a larger surface area could offer more active sites where hydrogen peroxide molecules can contact the catalyst and participate in the reaction. As mentioned before, the catalysts are mostly kept in challenging conditions in the hydrogen peroxide thrusters. It should be stable to mechanical and thermal stresses with good reaction activity. 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose prevents the cracking at low concentrations of H2O2. Then, higher calcination temperatures were tried to increase thermal resistance. Although the catalyst’s activity slightly decreased with increasing temperature, its strength improved. The critical parameter in the thruster is the catalyst stability. Instead of having high activity and decreasing performance in a short time, having moderate activity and a long operational life are the more efficient solutions for the catalyst in thruster applications. That is why, 800 °C and 900 °C calcination temperatures were selected to determine the microcrystalline cellulose effect on the highly concentrated hydrogen peroxide decomposition. 4.3 Monopropellant thruster test The 1 N hydrogen peroxide thruster was developed to determine the lifetime of the catalyst bed. The catalytic bed pressure was 15 bar, and it was designed for testing at sea level. The 87.5 % hydrogen peroxide propellant was supercharged by nitrogen gas at high pressure. Pressure was recorded at the different points of the catalytic bed. The pressure transducer had an accuracy of 0.19 bar %. As shown in Fig. 14, the propellant feeding system has manual valves, pressure regulators, and a solenoid valve. The pressure data were collected automatically by National Instruments DAQ. The long length of the catalytic bed was chosen so that it would be easier to figure out how the catalyst works. Long duration tests were carried out. The catalysts were loaded into the bed without being compressed to observe the mechanical endurance of the catalysts. From the characterization analysis, it was understood that the micro-cellulose loading increases the macropores on the catalyst and facilitates the exit of reaction products from the pores without the catalyst breaking. Also, with a higher calcination temperature, the catalyst's physical resistance improved. After that, the performance of these synthesized catalysts on the highly concentrated hydrogen peroxide decomposition was studied in 1 N thrusters. The pressure data were collected from the inlet and outlet of the catalytic bed. The difference between inlet and outlet pressures (∆P bed) shows the size change of the catalyst particles because as mentioned before, the catalytic bed was designed to only understand the mechanical stability of the catalyst. Hence, the breaking catalysts could lead to an increase in pressure loss (∆P bed) in the bed. This unexpected increase causes occlusion in the catalytic bed and instability in the thrusters. To analyze the effect of microcrystalline cellulose loading and higher calcination temperatures on the catalyst strength, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800, and MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 were tested and compared with MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 used as a baseline reference. To understand the catalyst characteristics, the results were analyzed with respect to catalyst particle size, pressure instability, and pressure drop inside the catalytic bed. The catalyst particle size distribution was measured before and after the test. Using a mesh filter, the particles produced by the catalyst during the test were collected. Also, according to Eq. (7), difference between the maximum and minimum catalytic bed pressure ratio to the average catalytic bed pressure gives the pressure instability in the catalytic bed. Also, the pressure drop on the catalyst bed (∆P bed) was calculated from the difference between the inlet pressure ( P in ) and catalytic bed pressure ( P c ) (Eq. (8)). (7) Pressure instability % = Pc max − Pc min Pc avg × 100 (8) Catalytic bed pressure drop ( ∆ P bed ) = P in − P c Fig. 15. illustrates the catalyst bed pressure-time variation for each catalyst test. Also, the steady-state performance results are summarized in Table 8. MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800, MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 catalysts were tested with similar durations. Thrusters with MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 and MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 catalysts showed unstable behavior because, in the middle of the tests, the pressure started to decrease in the bed (Fig. 15a and b). However, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 had the most durable performance during the test because its mechanical condition did not change, and the H2O2 could pass through the bed at constant pressure (Fig. 15c). In fact, the same catalyst was continued to be tested for a similar duration. There was still no change in stability, ∆P bed remains at 0.2 bar and 1 N thrust continued to be obtained. It is understood that MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 catalyst shows stable performance for durations twice as long as the other catalysts. In this study, 87.5 wt% H2O2 is used as a monopropellant where the decomposition temperature is below 900 °C. For higher concentrations over 95 wt% H2O2, the decomposition temperature is over 900 °C, which may be necessary to further increase the catalyst's calcination temperatures to be used in the thruster systems. Also, Table 8 demonstrates the average pressure drop and the pressure instability during the tests. In the tests, the pressure drop differences are 5.75 bar, 4.34 bar and 0.21 bar, respectively, and the pressure instability are 33.4 %, 30.8 % and 14.0 %, respectively. Mechanical and thermal shocks harm the catalyst and result in pressure instability and a greater pressure decrease through the catalyst bed. This is caused via fine particles produced inside the catalyst bed by the damaged catalyst pellets. As gaps inside the catalyst bed are generated, the pressure instability grows because of the inadequate packing of the catalyst bed. MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 illustrates a lower level of pressure instability and pressure decrease within the catalyst bed due to less damage compared to MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 and MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800. To investigate the mechanical strength of the catalysts in more detail, the pressure drop changes with time were plotted. In Fig. 16 the starting time of the occlusion can be more clearly observed for each catalyst. As seen, using MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 and MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 catalysts start to cause the occlusion in the bed approximately at 395.4 s, 504.6 s, and 835.5 s, respectively. In comparison to the MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 case, the steady-state operation maintained itself nearly twice as long in the MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 case. After the inflection point, a rapid increase in the pressure drop is observed in MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800. The rate of increase in pressure difference (∆P bed) in the tests is compared using the curve-fitting method. According to each of the linear fit slopes, MnOx/0 wt%Cel/Al2O3c800 represents the highest occlusion rate in the bed. When the microcrystalline cellulose templated catalysts are compared, the one that has a higher calcination temperature shows much lower occlusion. Therefore, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 demonstrates the least sensitivity to catalyst cracking. Fig. 17 demonstrates the generated fines mass percentages within the catalyst at the end of the tests. The distribution of catalyst particles are shown depending on their sizes. Before the test, 800–700 µm sized catalyst particles are selected to fill the catalyst bed. At the end of the test, sieve analysis is applied to determine how much catalyst had broken and what its size was. According to the analysis, MnOx/0 wt%CelAl2O3c800 has the highest mass percentage of the cracking catalyst particles. On the other hand, MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900 protects approximately 80 % of the initial particle size, and the results correlate well with the pressure drop behavior for each catalyst. 5 Conclusions Herein, a comprehensive analysis of the mechanical and thermal resistance of catalyst support was presented. Alumina with microcrystalline cellulose template was prepared, and a parametric study was done to determine the optimum preparation conditions. The 15 wt% of microcrystalline cellulose template to alumina at a calcination temperature of 900 °C was selected. The catalyst prepared in that condition had higher macropores, the highest fracture strength, and adequate reaction kinetics. The macropores contributed to the mechanical stability because they facilitate the exit of gas products of H2O2 decomposition from the catalyst pores. Also, the calcination temperature of 900 °C provided the thermal duration needed for the high decomposition temperature of hydrogen peroxide. The 87.5 % H2O2 decomposition tests was performed to understand the effect of microcrystalline cellulose on the catalyst stability in actual thruster operation conditions. The test of MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900catalyst showed an important enhancement in the stability of the catalyst since it had low fine particle formation, lower pressure instability, and a lower pressure drop. It was discovered that the MnOx/15 wt%Cel/Al2O3c900catalyst performed consistently for twice as long as the other catalysts. As a result, macropores were formed by microcrystalline cellulose template on MnOx/Alumina catalyst. Thanks to these pores, the hot gas was allowed to discharge from the pores without breaking the catalyst. In addition, by increasing the calcination temperature, catalysts with a longer life had been designed for thruster operations. Therefore, the unstable performance of thrusters caused by the cracking of the pellet catalyst can be solved by adjusting the porosity of the catalyst. For future studies, the developed catalyst with multiscale porosity should be tested with higher H2O2 concentrations and different thruster test conditions, such as cyclic and pulse modes. coredata.dc:description: The texture of the catalyst support is a crucial factor for H2O2 decomposition due to the expansion of H2O2 in monopropellant thrusters, which can lead to overpressure and catalyst breakage. Therefore, alumina supports with 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose templates were studied to create macropores. MIP and SEM analysis showed that microcrystalline cellulose template increases the macropore fraction. Low-concentration H2O2 decomposition experiments revealed that over 10 wt% microcrystalline cellulose prevented catalyst breakage. Additionally, the thermal durability of the catalyst was studied at different calcination temperatures. Alumina with 15 wt% microcrystalline cellulose and a 900 °C calcination temperature exhibited the highest fracture strength and suitable reaction kinetics. The catalysts were tested in high-concentration H2O2 monopropellant thruster. The results demonstrated enhancement in catalyst size retention, pressure stability, and pressure drop. Introducing macropores through microcrystalline cellulose addition overcomes unstable thruster performance and it extends catalyst lifespan in H2O2 monopropellant thrusters’ applications.
coredata.dc:title: Optimizing porosity of the catalyst for hydrogen peroxide based thrusters
